Randall, Kennedy was responsible for about one-third of the magazine’s contents each week. See Wallace Martin, The New Age under Orage
title: Keele University Archives (HUL 73). 34 Kennedy and Orage, the editor, co-wrote the regular columns ‘Notes of the Week’ and ‘Foreign Affairs’. Kennedy contributed other articles on issues ranging from politics and foreign affairs to philosophy and the arts, both under his own name and under the pseudonyms ‘S. Verdad’ and ‘Leighton Warnock’. According to Beatrice Hastings (whose account cannot be fully trusted given how explicitly bitter it is towards Orage), Kennedy was ‘Orage’s stand-by’, without whom ‘the paper might often have gone to pieces’: see Beatrice Hastings, The Old ‘New Age’: Orage – and Others

title: The Education Act of 1902 invested public funds in board and Church schools, with county councils taking over the supervision of non-fee paying schools from elected school boards. This enraged nonconformists and Liberal Unionists in equal measure. Though the Act passed through parliament during Salisbury’s reign, it was steered through the Commons by Balfour, who was the Leader of the House, and so was dubbed the ‘Balfour

In fact, in this, Ford was actually closely following Shaw in ‘Common Sense about the War’. Despite hating the war, Shaw made it clear that Germany needed to be defeated: because it had made itself ‘the exponent and champion in the modern world of the doctrine that military force is the basis and foundation of national greatness and military conquest the method by which the nation of the highest culture can impose that culture on its neighbours’.
